To me, the evidence showing the acceleration of the universe expansion actually shows that the universe is slowing down, not speeding up. When you are looking at a galaxy, lets say 20 million light years away, you are not seeing what it is doing at this exact second, but rather what it was doing 20 million years ago, as the speed of light is finite and it takes 20 million years for light to get here from that galaxy, we can only guess what it is doing at this exact moment based on what other galaxies are doing, as described in this video, but for me, guessing what a galaxy is doing isn't good enough. So, instead of guessing, let's use what we KNOW instead of what we THINK we know.

We KNOW that the galaxy 20 million light years away from us is moving away from us at, let's say 500km/s, so 20 million years ago, it's relative speed away from us was 500km/s. Then let's take a galaxy 10 million light years away and we find it was going at, let's say 300km/s away from us 10 million years ago. Finally, let's take a galaxy 30 million light years away from us and we find that it is moving, let's say 700km/s away from us 30 million years ago.
